verses.translation: Should a person commit evil, let him not do it again and again. Let him not find pleasure therein, for painful is the accumulation of evil.
verses.commentary: This verse warns against repeating evil actions and taking pleasure in them. When someone commits a wrong deed, they should feel remorse and resolve never to repeat it. Finding pleasure or satisfaction in evil deeds leads to their repetition and accumulation. The word 'uccayo' (accumulation) is significant - evil doesn't remain static but accumulates like compound interest, eventually bearing severe painful consequences. Each repetition of an evil deed strengthens the negative mental tendency and makes it harder to break free from that pattern of behavior.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Seyyasaka
story.content: Venerable Seyyasaka was a monk who became discontented with the monastic life. He was troubled by sexual desire and found it difficult to maintain his celibacy. His co-resident, the Elder Lāḷudāyī, instead of guiding him properly toward overcoming his defilements through meditation and right effort, gave him inappropriate advice. He advised Seyyasaka to masturbate to relieve his sexual frustration, saying it was a minor offense. Venerable Seyyasaka followed this misguided advice and committed this offense. However, having done it once and found temporary relief, he did it again. Then again. Soon it became a habit, and he fell into the same offense repeatedly, finding pleasure in this wrong action. The matter came to the attention of other monks, who reported it to the Buddha. The Buddha severely reproved both Seyyasaka for his repeated misconduct and Lāḷudāyī for his wrong guidance. The Buddha spoke this verse, emphasizing that even if one commits an evil deed, one should not repeat it or take pleasure in it, for the accumulation of evil leads to great suffering. The Buddha explained that each repetition strengthens the unwholesome tendency and makes liberation more difficult. Seyyasaka, hearing this teaching and realizing the gravity of his actions, felt deep remorse and resolved to overcome his defilements through proper practice.

verses.pali:
Puññañce puriso kayirā, kayirā naṁ punappunaṁ;
Tamhi chandaṁ kayirātha, sukho puññassa uccayo.
verses.translation: Should a person do good, let him do it again and again. Let him find pleasure therein, for blissful is the accumulation of merit.
verses.commentary: This verse is the positive counterpart to the previous one. Just as evil should not be repeated, good should be done repeatedly with joy. Finding pleasure in wholesome actions leads to their repetition and the accumulation of merit (puñña). Unlike evil accumulation which brings suffering, the accumulation of merit brings happiness both in this life and in future lives. The Buddha encourages developing enthusiasm for doing good, as this creates positive momentum in one's spiritual practice. Each good deed strengthens wholesome mental tendencies and makes future good actions easier and more natural.

story.title: The Story of the Female Deity
story.content: A young female deity who had been reborn in a celestial mansion near Jetavana monastery had accumulated great merit in her previous life as a human. Every day, she would descend from her mansion to clean the grounds around the monastery and the dwelling place of a certain Elder monk whom she particularly revered. She did this work joyfully and with great devotion, taking pleasure in serving the Sangha. One day, the Elder monk returned early from his alms-round and saw her cleaning his dwelling. Not knowing she was a deity, and thinking she was an overly devoted human woman, he told her firmly to stop coming and to cease this service, as it might give rise to wrong perceptions. The deity was deeply hurt by this rejection of her service. She stood there weeping, heartbroken that she could no longer perform the meritorious deed that brought her such joy. The Buddha, observing this situation with his divine eye, knew the deity's pure motivation and the Elder's misunderstanding. He came to the scene and consoled the weeping deity. He explained to the Elder that this was actually a celestial being who took great delight in performing meritorious service, and there was no impropriety in allowing her to continue. The Buddha then spoke this verse, praising the deity's joyful accumulation of merit. He explained that just as she had repeatedly performed good deeds in her previous life (which led to her divine rebirth), and just as she continued to delight in merit-making even in her celestial existence, all beings should find pleasure in doing good repeatedly, for the accumulation of merit brings only happiness and bliss. The deity, hearing this teaching, attained the fruit of Stream-entry. The Elder also learned an important lesson about not discouraging others' wholesome enthusiasm in performing meritorious deeds.

verses.pali:
Pāpopi passati bhadraṁ, yāva pāpaṁ na paccati;
Yadā ca paccati pāpaṁ, atha pāpo pāpāni passati.
verses.translation: Even an evil-doer sees good fortune as long as evil has not ripened. But when evil ripens, then the evil-doer sees the evil results.
verses.commentary: This verse explains the principle of karmic ripening. A person who commits evil deeds may continue to enjoy good fortune for some time if they still have past good karma that hasn't yet exhausted itself. This can create the illusion that evil actions have no consequences. However, this is only temporary. When the evil karma matures and bears fruit, the evildoer will inevitably experience painful results. This teaching addresses the common observation that some wicked people seem to prosper, which might cause doubt about the law of karma. The Buddha explains that this is merely a delay, not an exemption from consequences.

story.title: The Story of Anāthapiṇḍika
story.content: Anāthapiṇḍika was one of the Buddha's chief lay supporters and was renowned for his extraordinary generosity. He supported the Sangha so generously that he used up the greater part of his enormous fortune in building monasteries, offering alms, and supporting monks. As his wealth diminished, some people began to criticize him severely. They said he was foolish and reckless, wasting his family's inheritance on religious donations. They predicted he would end up a pauper. Even a guardian deity who lived in his house became concerned and appeared to him one night. The deity criticized him for his extravagant almsgiving and advised him to be more moderate and focus on rebuilding his business and wealth instead of giving everything away to monks. However, Anāthapiṇḍika ignored all this criticism and continued his generous acts without hesitation, confident in the Buddha's teaching about the fruits of generosity. At one point, his wealth was so depleted that people thought he was finished. But then, unexpectedly, ships that everyone thought had been lost at sea returned laden with valuable goods. Debtors who had been unable to pay suddenly repaid their loans. New business opportunities arose. Within a short time, Anāthapiṇḍika became even wealthier than before. The guardian deity, seeing this reversal, realized her mistake and came to beg for forgiveness. Anāthapiṇḍika, being compassionate, forgave her but took her to see the Buddha so she could receive proper teaching. The Buddha spoke these two verses (119 and 120) to illustrate how the ripening of karma works. He explained that wicked people may seem to prosper temporarily because they are still enjoying the fruits of their past good karma. But when that good karma is exhausted and their evil deeds ripen, they will face terrible consequences. Conversely, good people like Anāthapiṇḍika may face temporary difficulties when past negative karma ripens, but when their good deeds bear fruit, they experience abundant happiness and prosperity. This is why one should never judge the validity of karma by immediate results, but should have faith in its inevitable operation over time.

verses.pali:
Bhadropi passati pāpaṁ, yāva bhadraṁ na paccati;
Yadā ca paccati bhadraṁ, atha bhadro bhadrāni passati.
verses.translation: Even a good person sees misfortune as long as good has not ripened. But when good ripens, then the good person sees the good results.
verses.commentary: This verse is the complement to the previous one, explaining that virtuous people may temporarily experience misfortune when their past negative karma ripens, even while they are currently performing good deeds. This can be discouraging and may cause some to doubt the efficacy of virtue. However, when their wholesome karma matures, they will certainly experience happiness and good fortune. This teaching provides encouragement to continue in virtue even when facing adversity, understanding that current difficulties are merely the exhaustion of old negative karma, while the good being done now will surely bear fruit in due time.

story.title: Continuation of Anāthapiṇḍika's Story
story.content: This verse was spoken together with verse 119 in the same context of Anāthapiṇḍika's story. When Anāthapiṇḍika brought the guardian deity to the Buddha, the Buddha elaborated on the principle of karmic ripening for both evil and good. He explained that Anāthapiṇḍika's temporary financial difficulties, despite his current virtuous actions, were due to some minor negative karma from the past that needed to exhaust itself. The Buddha might have been referring to instances in Anāthapiṇḍika's past when he was building his merchant empire and may have engaged in some of the harsh business practices common to merchants. But because Anāthapiṇḍika continued to perform good deeds with pure motivation, not discouraged by temporary setbacks, his abundant good karma eventually ripened, bringing him even greater wealth than before. The Buddha used this example to teach that one should not be discouraged from doing good even when facing difficulties, nor should one feel proud when experiencing good fortune, thinking oneself exempt from consequences of past misdeeds. The key is to understand that both good and evil karma will ripen in their own time according to conditions. The wise person continues to cultivate virtue regardless of present circumstances, knowing that wholesome actions will inevitably bear wholesome fruit. Similarly, one should not be deceived by the temporary prosperity of the wicked or the temporary suffering of the good. These are merely surface appearances that will change when different karmic seeds ripen. This teaching gave great confidence to Anāthapiṇḍika and the deity, and strengthened their faith in the Dhamma and the law of karma.

verses.translation: Do not think lightly of evil, saying 'It will not come to me.' By the falling of drops even a water-jar is filled. Likewise the fool, gathering little by little, fills himself with evil.
verses.commentary: This verse warns against underestimating small evils. People often dismiss minor wrongdoings, thinking they won't lead to serious consequences. However, just as a large vessel is filled by accumulating water drop by drop, a person becomes filled with evil by accumulating small misdeeds. The simile is powerful - a single drop of water seems insignificant and couldn't possibly fill a jar. Yet given time and repetition, drops accumulate into a full vessel. Similarly, small lies, minor acts of unkindness, petty thefts, and other seemingly insignificant misdeeds accumulate to create a personality dominated by evil tendencies. This verse complements verse 117's warning against repeating evil by emphasizing that even small evils matter.

story.title: The Story of a Careless Monk
story.content: There was a monk who was careless about minor rules and duties. After using beds, chairs, and other monastery equipment, he would leave them outside without putting them away properly. The rain would damage them, and white ants would eat into the wood. When other monks advised him to be more careful and to put things away after use, he dismissed their concerns saying, 'This is such a small matter. What harm can it do? These are just material things. Why worry about such trifles?' He continued his careless behavior, leaving monastery property exposed to the elements day after day. The damage gradually accumulated. What had been good furniture slowly deteriorated. The other monks became increasingly concerned, not just about the material loss but about this monk's attitude of dismissing small wrongdoings. They felt this casual attitude toward minor infractions could lead to greater misconduct. Finally, they reported the matter to the Buddha. The Buddha summoned the careless monk and admonished him strongly. The Buddha explained that he should not disregard even a slight wrong, thinking it wouldn't matter or wouldn't affect him. The Buddha spoke this verse, using the simile of the water jar. He explained: 'Just as a large jar becomes completely full by the accumulation of tiny water drops, one drop at a time, so too does a fool become filled with evil by accumulating small misdeeds, bit by bit. You think these small acts of carelessness don't matter, but they accumulate. Your mind is being trained in carelessness and disregard for rules. Today it is furniture left outside. Tomorrow it might be more serious precepts you regard lightly. The pattern of dismissing small wrongs is itself a great wrong, for it leads to greater transgressions.' Chastened by this teaching, the monk recognized his error. He realized that his attitude of 'it's just a small thing' was actually developing an unwholesome character trait. He reformed his behavior and became careful even about minor matters. The Buddha also used this occasion to lay down a formal training rule for all monks to properly care for and put away monastery property after use, preventing damage from weather and pests. This rule helps train monks in mindfulness and respect for material requisites, and prevents the gradual accumulation of carelessness and disregard for rules.

verses.translation: Do not think lightly of good, saying 'It will not come to me.' By the falling of drops even a water-jar is filled. Likewise the wise person, gathering little by little, fills himself with good.
verses.commentary: This verse is the positive counterpart to verse 121. Just as small evils should not be underestimated, small good deeds should not be dismissed as insignificant. People often fail to do small acts of kindness, thinking 'this won't make any difference' or 'such a small good deed won't benefit me.' However, just as drops accumulate to fill a vessel, small good deeds accumulate to fill one's character with virtue. The wise person (dhīro) understands this and diligently accumulates merit even through small acts. Unlike the fool who dismisses both small evils and small goods, the wise person respects the cumulative power of repeated small actions, whether good or bad.

story.title: The Story of Bīlālapadaka the Miser
story.content: In Sāvatthī, there lived a very wealthy but extremely miserly millionaire named Bīlālapadaka. He got his nickname (which means 'one who gives a lick') because he was so stingy that when he ate sweet foods, he wouldn't give even a lick to anyone else - not even to his own wife or children. He hoarded his wealth and never gave anything in charity. He wouldn't even spend money on good food for himself, eating only the cheapest meals. When he wanted to eat something special, he would take his wife to a secret chamber in his house where no one could see them, and they would eat alone, making sure not a morsel was seen by anyone else who might ask for a share. He thought to himself: 'Why should I waste my wealth on others? Why should I do good deeds that give away my money? Such small acts of giving won't make any difference anyway. What benefit could come from a few small acts of charity?' Despite his wealth, he died without ever enjoying it or using it for any good purpose. After death, due to his extreme miserliness and lack of any merit from generosity, he was reborn as a preta (hungry ghost) in the hell realm, suffering from constant hunger and thirst. His enormous wealth was inherited by the king's treasury, as he had no heirs who knew where he had hidden it all. Meanwhile, his wife, who had gone along with his miserly ways, also died and was reborn in a similar state of misery. Some monks, knowing this story, asked the Buddha about Bīlālapadaka's fate. The Buddha related his current state of suffering and explained that his miserliness had prevented him from accumulating any merit. The Buddha then spoke this verse to teach the opposite lesson - that one should not dismiss small acts of merit, thinking they won't make a difference. He explained: 'Just as a vessel becomes full by the accumulation of small drops of water, so too does a wise person become filled with merit by accumulating small good deeds, bit by bit. Bīlālapadaka thought small acts of generosity wouldn't matter or benefit him, so he did no good at all. But if he had understood this principle, he could have enjoyed his wealth by using it skillfully for both his own happiness and the welfare of others, and he would have accumulated merit that would have led to a fortunate rebirth.' The Buddha emphasized that no good deed is too small to matter. Each small act of kindness, each small offering, each small service to others accumulates. A smile, a kind word, offering a drink of water, helping someone with a small task - these all accumulate to create a character of goodness and generate positive karma. The wise person understands this and never misses an opportunity to do even small good deeds, knowing they accumulate into great benefit.

verses.pali:
Vāṇijo'va bhayaṁ maggaṁ, appasattho mahaddhano;
Visaṁ jīvitukāmo'va, pāpāni parivajjaye.
verses.translation: Just as a merchant with a small escort and great wealth avoids a perilous route, just as one desiring to live avoids poison, even so should one shun evil things.
verses.commentary: This verse uses two vivid similes to illustrate how carefully one should avoid evil. A wise merchant carrying valuable goods with insufficient protection would naturally avoid dangerous roads frequented by robbers. Similarly, anyone who wants to live would instinctively avoid deadly poison. In the same way, and with the same degree of care and wisdom, one should avoid evil actions, evil companions, and evil situations. The comparison suggests that engaging in evil is as foolish and dangerous as a rich merchant with little security walking through bandit territory, or as someone deliberately consuming poison. Both the temporal and spiritual consequences of evil are severe and should be avoided with great care and wisdom.

story.title: The Story of the Merchant and the Robbers
story.content: A wealthy merchant was traveling with a caravan carrying valuable goods. His caravan was large, but most of the travelers were not fighters - they were fellow merchants, their families, and servants. The group had little protection against robbers. Accompanying the caravan were several monks who were also traveling to their destination. Word reached a band of robbers that a wealthy merchant with a large caravan but little security was passing through their region. The robbers began to plan an ambush, intending to rob the caravan and possibly harm or kill those who resisted. However, the merchant had heard rumors about these robbers and their dangerous territory. Being a wise man, he decided to alter his route, even though it would take longer. He told the caravan they would avoid the main road through the dangerous area and instead take a longer, more circuitous route through safer territory. Some travelers complained about the delay, but the merchant insisted, saying it was better to arrive late than not to arrive at all. His caution proved wise. The robbers waited in vain for the caravan on the main road, while the merchant and his group safely passed through an alternate route and reached their destination without incident. The monks who were traveling with the caravan witnessed all this. When they continued on to visit the Buddha, they related this story to him, commenting on the merchant's wisdom in avoiding danger. The Buddha replied that this was indeed wise, and then spoke this verse. He explained: 'Just as that merchant, carrying great wealth with little protection, wisely avoided the dangerous road where robbers lay in wait, so too should all beings avoid evil deeds with great care. Just as a person who wishes to live carefully avoids consuming poison, so should one carefully avoid evil actions, evil speech, and evil thoughts. The merchant understood that the risk of taking the dangerous route far outweighed the inconvenience of taking a longer path. Similarly, one should understand that the consequences of evil - both in this life and in future lives - far outweigh any temporary pleasure or advantage that might be gained from wrongdoing.' The Buddha further explained that evil actions are like poison - they may sometimes be attractive or seem beneficial in the moment, but they lead to suffering and death (spiritual death, or rebirth in lower realms). Just as no one knowingly drinks poison hoping to live, no one should engage in evil hoping for happiness. The monks and other listeners deeply appreciated this teaching and became even more careful in avoiding all forms of evil, understanding that the consequences of evil are as dangerous as robbers to a wealthy merchant or poison to one who desires to live.

verses.pali:
Pāṇimhi ce vaṇo nāssa, hareyya pāṇinā visaṁ;
Nābbaṇaṁ visam anveti, natthi pāpaṁ akubbato.
verses.translation: If there is no wound in one's hand, one may carry poison in it. Poison does not affect one who has no wound. There is no evil for one who does no wrong.
verses.commentary: This verse uses a medical analogy to explain spiritual purity. Poison cannot enter the body through intact skin - it needs a wound or opening to cause harm. Similarly, evil cannot harm someone who does no evil. The 'wound' represents engagement in wrongdoing - those who commit evil create an opening through which the consequences of evil can enter and harm them. But one who maintains purity of conduct, speech, and thought - who does no wrong - is like someone with unwounded hands safely carrying poison. External evil circumstances cannot truly harm such a person because there is no internal evil to connect with them. This verse has been interpreted in several ways: it may refer to the Arahant who can dwell among evil without being corrupted, or to anyone who maintains purity despite external temptations.

story.title: The Story of the Stream-Winner Woman and the Hunter
story.content: In a village near Sāvatthī, there lived a rich man's daughter who had attained the fruit of Stream-Entry (Sotāpanna) through hearing the Buddha's teachings. Despite her spiritual attainment, owing to strong past karma, she fell in love with a hunter. Her parents were horrified - their daughter, who had achieved such a high spiritual state, wanted to marry a man who made his living by killing animals! They tried to dissuade her, but the karmic connection was too strong. Eventually, she eloped with the hunter and went to live with him in the forest. They lived a simple life in a small hut in the jungle, and she gave birth to several sons. Although she was a Stream-Winner who understood the Dhamma and had eliminated certain defilements, she continued to live with her husband and even assisted him in his work. When the hunter would go out to hunt, she would give him his bow and arrows. She would help him prepare the meat of the animals he killed. To outward appearances, she was fully participating in the livelihood of killing. Other monks who knew about her past and her attainment of Stream-Entry were disturbed by this situation. They thought she had fallen from her attainment, or that she must be accumulating terrible karma by helping her husband kill animals. They reported this matter to the Buddha, expressing their concern and confusion. How could a Stream-Winner be involved in such activities? The Buddha explained the situation using this verse. He said: 'This woman has no wound - she has attained Stream-Entry and eliminated the view of self, doubt, and attachment to rites and rituals. Though she lives with a hunter and outwardly assists him, she does not actually commit the evil of killing. She does no wrong herself. Her mind remains pure, without the intention to kill or harm. She is merely supporting her husband as a wife, but she creates no killing karma herself because she commits no act of killing with the intention to kill.' The Buddha continued: 'Just as poison cannot harm a hand that has no wound in it, so evil cannot truly harm one who does no evil. Though she handles the weapons of killing and lives in an environment of killing, she herself does not kill, does not intend to kill, and does not rejoice in killing. Therefore, the evil of killing does not touch her, just as poison placed in an unwounded hand does not enter the body.' The Buddha further explained that due to her attainment of Stream-Entry, it was impossible for her to deliberately kill any living being. Even though past karma had brought her to live in these circumstances, her mind remained pure of that particular evil. The monks asked whether she wouldn't accumulate bad karma through association and assistance. The Buddha clarified that while there might be minor negative consequences from such close association with wrong livelihood, she was not creating the heavy karma of killing because she lacked the direct intention and action of killing. Her hands were 'unwounded' - her mind was free from the defilement of cruelty and the intention to harm. This teaching illustrates an important principle: it is primarily one's own intentional actions and the state of one's own mind that determine one's karma and spiritual state. While we should certainly avoid proximity to evil and avoid even the appearance of wrongdoing, the crucial factor is whether we ourselves engage in wrong action with wrong intention. This verse has also been interpreted to refer to Arahants who, having completely purified their minds of all defilements, can be exposed to evil influences without being corrupted by them, just as poison cannot harm an unwounded hand. They may live in the world surrounded by various forms of evil, but because they do no evil themselves and have no defilements through which evil could take root, they remain completely pure and untainted.

verses.pali:
Yo appaduṭṭhassa narassa dussati, suddhassa posassa anaṅgaṇassa;
Tameva bālaṁ pacceti pāpaṁ, sukhumo rajo paṭivātaṁ'va khitto.
verses.translation: Whoever harms an innocent person, one who is pure and blameless, upon that very fool the evil recoils like fine dust thrown against the wind.
verses.commentary: This verse warns of the boomerang effect of harming innocent people. When someone wrongs a person who is pure, blameless, and without fault, the evil deed returns to harm the perpetrator, just as fine dust thrown into the wind blows back into the thrower's face. The 'pure person' (suddha) particularly refers to Arahants and noble ones, but applies to anyone innocent. The evil karma inevitably returns with great force.

story.title: The Story of Koka the Hunter
story.content: Koka was a hunter who made his living by killing animals. One day, while hunting in the forest, he encountered the paccekabuddha (Silent Buddha) named Sunetta. The paccekabuddha was on his alms-round walking peacefully through the forest. Koka, driven by evil thoughts or perhaps just cruel sport, shot an arrow at the innocent Sunetta. The arrow struck the paccekabuddha, who died from the wound. This was a grave evil - killing an enlightened being who had harmed no one and was completely pure and blameless. The consequences came swiftly. Koka returned to his village, but his evil deed had created immediate karmic results. The very same day, the earth opened up beneath him and he fell into Avīci, the most terrible hell realm, where he experienced unimaginable suffering. The Buddha related this story and spoke this verse to show that harming the innocent and pure brings immediate and severe consequences. Just as dust thrown against the wind flies back into the face of the thrower, so evil done to the blameless returns to harm the evildoer.

verses.pali:
Gabbhameke'papajjanti, nirayaṁ pāpakammino;
Saggaṁ sugatino yanti, parinibbanti anāsavā.
verses.translation: Some are reborn in the womb, evildoers go to hell, the righteous go to heaven, but those who are free from mental pollutants attain Nibbāna.
verses.commentary: This verse describes four possible destinations after death based on one's karma. Most beings are reborn in the womb (human or animal realm) based on mixed karma. Those who have committed grave evil go to hell (niraya). Those who have lived righteously go to heaven (sagga). But the Arahants, free from all mental defilements (anāsavā), attain final Nibbāna and are not reborn anywhere. This verse presents the Buddhist cosmology of rebirth destinations, emphasizing that liberation from the cycle is possible only through eliminating all defilements.

story.title: The Story of Tissabh Monk Who Made Golden Ornaments
story.content: Venerable Tissa was a goldsmith before becoming a monk. Even after ordination, he continued to practice his craft skillfully, sometimes making ornaments for the monastery or repairing items. Other monks noticed that he seemed to take great pleasure in working with gold, and some wondered if he was still attached to his former profession. When the Buddha was asked about Tissa's future, he explained that Tissa, though he handled gold, did so without attachment and with pure intentions. The Buddha spoke this verse to explain the various destinations beings reach after death. He said that those with evil karma go to hell, those with good karma go to heaven, ordinary beings are reborn in the womb, but Arahants like Tissa, who are free from all defilements, will attain Parinibbāna and not be reborn anywhere.

verses.pali:
Na antalikkhe na samuddamajjhe, na pabbatānaṁ vivaraṁ pavissa;
Na vijjati so jagatippadeso, yatthaṭṭhito mucceyya pāpakammā.
verses.translation: Not in the sky, nor in the middle of the ocean, nor by entering a mountain cave - nowhere in the world is there a place where one can escape from the results of evil deeds.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes the inescapability of karmic consequences. No matter where one goes - to the sky, the depths of the ocean, or hidden caves in mountains - there is no place in the entire world where one can hide from the results of evil karma. This teaching dispels the notion that one can escape karmic consequences through physical relocation or hiding. Karma follows the doer like a shadow, and only by experiencing its results or through profound spiritual purification can one be free from it.

story.title: The Story of the King of Kosala
story.content: King Pasenadi of Kosala had committed some evil deeds in his past. As he grew older and more reflective, he became worried about the consequences of his actions. He thought perhaps he could escape these consequences by going to a place where the results of his karma couldn't reach him. He asked the Buddha: 'Is there any place where I could go to escape from the results of my evil deeds?' The Buddha replied with this verse, explaining that there is nowhere in the world - not in the sky, not in the ocean, not in mountain caves - where one can hide from one's karma. The Buddha continued: 'However, there is a way to purify evil karma - through regret, moral conduct, good deeds, and ultimately through wisdom and meditation that purify the mind. While you cannot run away from karma, you can face it with courage, accept its results with equanimity, and work to create new good karma and purify your mind through the practice of Dhamma.'

verses.pali:
Na antalikkhe na samuddamajjhe, na pabbatānaṁ vivaraṁ pavissa;
Na vijjati so jagatippadeso, yatthaṭṭhitaṁ nappasaheyya maccu.
verses.translation: Not in the sky, nor in the middle of the ocean, nor by entering a mountain cave - nowhere in the world is there a place where one will not be overcome by death.
verses.commentary: This verse is parallel to verse 127 but focuses on the inevitability of death rather than karma. Death is universal and inescapable. No matter where one goes or hides, death will eventually find everyone. This teaching on the inevitability of death serves as a reminder of urgency in spiritual practice. Since death is certain and its time uncertain, one should not delay in practicing the Dhamma. The only escape from death is not through hiding but through attaining Nibbāna, which transcends birth and death entirely.

story.title: The Story of Suppabuddha the Leper
story.content: Suppabuddha was a leper who lived in great suffering. One day he heard the Buddha teaching and his mind was greatly inspired. He listened attentively to the Dhamma and attained Stream-Entry. After the discourse, he approached the Buddha to pay respects. The Buddha, knowing Suppabuddha's karma, warned him to be careful on his way home. However, Suppabuddha was so filled with joy from his attainment that he wasn't as cautious as usual. That very evening, as he was walking home, a cow that had just given birth to a calf became agitated and gored him to death. The monks found his body and asked the Buddha what would happen to him. The Buddha replied that Suppabuddha had been reborn in the Tāvatiṁsa heaven due to his attainment of Stream-Entry. The monks then asked why, if the Buddha knew he would die, he didn't prevent it more forcefully. The Buddha explained that there was no place where Suppabuddha could have hidden from death when his time had come. The Buddha spoke this verse, teaching that death is inescapable. He explained: 'Death cannot be avoided by going to the sky, diving into the ocean, or hiding in mountain caves. There is nowhere in this world where death cannot reach. This is why one must practice the Dhamma urgently and diligently, for we never know when death will come. Suppabuddha was fortunate - though he died, he died as a Stream-Winner, ensuring his ultimate liberation within seven more lifetimes at most. This is why attaining the Dhamma in this very life is so important - we cannot escape death, but we can attain liberation before death comes.'

chapters.summary: This chapter addresses the consequences of causing harm to others and emphasizes non-violence, compassion, and the universal desire for happiness and freedom from suffering.

verses.pali:
Sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa, sabbe bhāyanti maccuno;
Attānaṁ upamaṁ katvā, na haneyya na ghātaye.
verses.translation: All tremble at punishment; all fear death. Comparing oneself with others, one should neither kill nor cause another to kill.
verses.commentary: This verse establishes the principle of empathy as the foundation for non-violence. The word 'daṇḍa' means rod, stick, or punishment, representing any form of violence or harm. The Buddha teaches that just as we ourselves fear punishment and death, so do all other beings. By putting ourselves in another's place (attānaṁ upamaṁ katvā), we naturally develop compassion and refrain from harming. This is the Buddhist version of the Golden Rule - treat others as you would wish to be treated, because others feel just as you do.

story.title: The Story of the Group of Six Monks
story.content: In the Jetavana monastery, a group of seventeen monks were cleaning and preparing a dwelling place with the intention of staying there during the rainy season retreat. They worked hard to make it suitable. While they were doing this, a group of six monks (the Chabbaggiya monks, who were notorious for their misconduct) arrived at the scene. Seeing the nicely prepared dwelling, these six monks said to the group of seventeen, 'We are your seniors in ordination. According to the rules, we have the right to this dwelling. You juniors should give way to us. This place is ours now.' The group of seventeen monks replied, 'Venerable brothers, we saw this place first and we have worked hard to prepare it. We should be allowed to stay here.' The six monks, being arrogant and disrespectful of proper conduct, became angry. They said, 'You dare to argue with your seniors? We will teach you a lesson!' They then violently assaulted the seventeen monks, beating them with their fists and whatever objects were at hand. The seventeen monks cried out in pain and fear for their lives. Other monks heard the commotion and came running. They found the younger monks injured and distressed, and the six monks standing over them defiantly. The matter was immediately reported to the Buddha. The Buddha summoned both groups of monks. He severely reprimanded the group of six, saying, 'This is a grave offense. You have violated the fundamental principles of the Dhamma. How can you, who have left the household life to follow the path of peace and liberation, engage in violence against your own brothers in the Sangha?' The Buddha then spoke this verse to all the monks assembled: 'All tremble at punishment; all fear death. Comparing oneself with others, one should neither kill nor cause another to kill.' The Buddha explained: 'Just as you fear being struck and fear death, so do all other beings. Put yourself in their place. How would you feel if someone beat you? How would you feel facing death? When you truly understand that others feel exactly as you do, how can you raise your hand against them?' Following this incident, the Buddha laid down a formal training rule (Vinaya rule) prohibiting monks from physically striking or assaulting others. This was one of many rules established to maintain peace and harmony in the monastic community.

verses.pali:
Sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa, sabbesaṁ jīvitaṁ piyaṁ;
Attānaṁ upamaṁ katvā, na haneyya na ghātaye.
verses.translation: All tremble at punishment; life is dear to all. Comparing oneself with others, one should neither kill nor cause another to kill.
verses.commentary: This verse reinforces the message of the previous one, adding the phrase 'life is dear to all' (sabbesaṁ jīvitaṁ piyaṁ). Every living being cherishes its own life and wishes to continue living. This natural love of life is universal. Understanding this universal truth should prevent us from taking life or causing others to take life. The repetition emphasizes the importance of this teaching and the need to deeply internalize the principle of empathy and non-violence.

story.title: Continuation of the Group of Six Monks Story
story.content: After the Buddha had reprimanded the group of six monks and established the rule against physical violence, these same monks continued their troublesome behavior. Not long after the first incident, the same two groups of monks had another dispute over the same dwelling place. The group of six monks again tried to claim it as their right due to seniority. This time, however, because the Buddha had already laid down a rule prohibiting striking others, the six monks did not actually beat the seventeen monks. Instead, they raised their hands threateningly, made menacing gestures, and shouted intimidating words. They stood over the younger monks with clenched fists raised, as if about to strike. The seventeen monks, remembering the previous beating and seeing these threatening gestures, cried out in fear, believing they were about to be attacked again. Even though they were not actually struck this time, the terror they felt was real. Once again, other monks heard the disturbance and reported it to the Buddha. The Buddha summoned the group of six monks again. He said, 'Not only have you failed to learn from your previous misconduct, but you continue to terrorize your fellow monks. Do you not understand that threatening violence is itself a form of violence? Even if you do not actually strike them, you cause them to experience fear and suffering.' The Buddha then spoke this verse, emphasizing that life is dear to all beings. He explained: 'These seventeen monks love their lives just as you love yours. They fear harm and death just as you would. When you threaten them, even without touching them, you cause them genuine suffering because they fear for their lives. This too is wrong.' The Buddha then laid down another disciplinary rule forbidding monks from raising their hands or making threatening gestures toward others. The Buddha's teaching here shows that non-violence extends beyond refraining from actual physical harm - it includes avoiding threats, intimidation, and causing fear in others. The principle of empathy requires us to consider not just the physical effects of our actions but also the psychological and emotional suffering we might cause.

verses.pali:
Sukhakāmāni bhūtāni, yo daṇḍena vihiṁsati;
Attano sukham esāno, pecca so na labhate sukhaṁ.
verses.translation: Whoever, seeking his own happiness, harms with violence other pleasure-loving beings, he does not find happiness hereafter.
verses.commentary: This verse explains the karmic consequences of violence. All beings desire happiness (sukhakāma) and try to avoid suffering. When someone, in pursuit of their own happiness, causes suffering to other beings through violence, they create negative karma that prevents them from finding happiness in future lives. This is the law of cause and effect in action - violence leads to suffering for the perpetrator, not to the happiness they sought. The irony is that by trying to secure happiness through harming others, one ensures future unhappiness.

story.title: The Story of the Boys and the Snake
story.content: One day, the Buddha was walking on an alms-round in Sāvatthī when he came across a group of young boys playing near the roadside. The boys had found a snake and, afraid that it might bite them, they were beating it with sticks and stones. Some boys were laughing and treating it as sport, while others claimed they were just trying to kill it before it could harm anyone. The snake was writhing in pain, trying desperately to escape, but the boys surrounded it and continued their assault. The Buddha stopped and watched for a moment. Then he approached the boys and asked them, 'Why are you beating this snake?' The boys replied, 'Venerable Sir, we are afraid this snake might bite us or bite other people. Snakes are dangerous. We are killing it to protect ourselves and others. We are seeking safety and happiness by removing this danger.' The Buddha looked at them with compassion and said, 'Tell me, do you boys wish to be happy? Do you wish to live and enjoy life?' 'Yes, Venerable Sir,' they replied, 'of course we want to be happy and to live.' 'Do you fear pain and death?' the Buddha asked. 'Yes, Venerable Sir,' they answered, 'we fear pain and we fear death very much.' The Buddha then said, 'Look at this snake. It too wishes to be happy. It too wishes to live. It too fears pain and death, just as you do. Out of fear, you are beating this creature. But this snake has done nothing to you. It was simply resting here when you found it. You are causing it terrible suffering.' The Buddha continued, 'You say you are seeking happiness and safety for yourselves. But by harming this creature that also seeks happiness, you are actually creating the causes for your own future suffering. The karma of violence will follow you and prevent you from finding the very happiness you seek.' Then the Buddha spoke this verse: 'Whoever, seeking his own happiness, harms with violence other pleasure-loving beings, he does not find happiness hereafter.' The Buddha explained further: 'When you understand that all beings desire happiness just as you do, and fear suffering just as you do, you will naturally develop compassion. Instead of harming out of fear, you should practice kindness even toward creatures you fear. The snake wants only to live its life. If you leave it alone, it will go its own way and cause you no harm. But if you attack it, you may provoke it to defend itself, and you create negative karma that will prevent your future happiness.' The boys, hearing this teaching, felt remorse for their actions. They stopped beating the snake and let it escape. From that day forward, they were more careful not to harm living beings unnecessarily, even those they feared. The Buddha used this incident to teach an important lesson: that violence born of fear, or violence justified as seeking happiness and safety, still creates negative karma and leads to suffering. True happiness cannot be built on the suffering of other beings.

verses.pali:
Sukhakāmāni bhūtāni, yo daṇḍena na hiṁsati;
Attano sukham esāno, pecca so labhate sukhaṁ.
verses.translation: Whoever, seeking his own happiness, does not harm with violence other pleasure-loving beings, he finds happiness hereafter.
verses.commentary: This verse is the positive counterpart to verse 131. It teaches that one who seeks happiness but refrains from harming other beings who also seek happiness will find genuine happiness in future lives. The path to true happiness is through non-violence and compassion, not through harming others. This verse emphasizes that happiness and non-harming are aligned, not contradictory. By respecting the happiness of others, we create the causes for our own future happiness.

story.title: Continuation of the Boys and Snake Story
story.content: After the Buddha had taught the boys about the karmic consequences of violence, he elaborated on the positive path. He said to them, 'Listen well, young ones. Just as harming others in pursuit of your own happiness leads to future suffering, refraining from harm leads to future happiness.' The Buddha explained: 'If you see a snake and you fear it, you can simply move away. You can warn others to be careful. You can even gently guide it away from places where people walk. All of this can be done without violence and without harming the snake. When you seek your own safety and happiness in this way - without causing suffering to other beings - you create positive karma that will bring you happiness in this life and future lives.' The Buddha gave them practical advice: 'When you encounter creatures that frighten you, remember that they are also frightened - often more frightened of you than you are of them. Most creatures do not wish to harm humans; they only defend themselves when attacked. If you approach all beings with the understanding that they too seek happiness and fear suffering, you will naturally act with kindness and compassion. This kindness creates positive karma.' Then the Buddha spoke this verse: 'Whoever, seeking his own happiness, does not harm with violence other pleasure-loving beings, he finds happiness hereafter.' The boys took this teaching to heart. They not only stopped harming snakes and other creatures, but they actively began to practice kindness toward all living beings. They would carefully move insects out of harm's way, warn people about dangerous animals rather than killing them, and treat all creatures with respect. Their changed behavior became an example in their community. As these boys grew up practicing non-violence and compassion, they found that happiness came naturally to them. They had good relationships, felt at peace with themselves, and their lives were marked by good fortune. This was the immediate karmic result of their wholesome actions. The Buddha used these two verses (131 and 132) to teach a fundamental principle: our pursuit of happiness should never come at the expense of other beings' wellbeing. True, lasting happiness can only be found through the path of non-harming and compassion.

verses.pali:
Māvoca pharusaṁ kañci, vuttā paṭivadeyyu taṁ;
Dukkha hi sāruppa kathā, paṭidaṇḍā phuseyyu taṁ.
verses.translation: Speak not harshly to anyone. Those thus spoken to will retort. Painful indeed is vindictive speech. Blows in exchange may bruise you.
verses.commentary: This verse warns against harsh speech and its consequences. When we speak harshly to others, they naturally respond in kind, leading to an escalating cycle of verbal violence. The Buddha warns that such aggressive speech is painful (dukkha) and can lead to physical violence - 'blows in exchange' (paṭidaṇḍā). Harsh words hurt both the speaker and the listener, and often provoke retaliation. The wise person therefore guards their speech carefully, speaking gently even when provoked. This verse extends the principle of non-violence from physical actions to verbal actions.

story.title: The Story of Several Children
story.content: In Sāvatthī, there were several children who often played together near the marketplace. These children came from different families and had different temperaments. Among them were a few who had developed the habit of speaking roughly to others - using insulting language, mocking others, and shouting aggressively when they didn't get their way. One day, the group was playing a game when a dispute arose over the rules. One of the rough-spoken children began shouting insults at another child, calling him stupid and worthless. The insulted child, hurt and angry, shouted back even harsher insults. The first child escalated with cruder language. Soon both were screaming at each other with increasingly vicious words. Other children joined in, taking sides, and the verbal abuse spread through the whole group. Parents and neighbors heard the commotion. Some adults tried to intervene, but the children's anger had reached such a pitch that they ignored the adults. The verbal fight continued to escalate. Finally, one child, unable to contain his rage any longer, pushed another child violently. That child fell and hit his head on a stone, beginning to bleed. The pushed child's older brother, seeing his sibling injured, attacked the first child with his fists. Within moments, what had started as a game had become a violent brawl. Several children were injured, some seriously. Parents had to physically separate the fighting children. The incident created bad feelings between families in the neighborhood that lasted for a long time. Some monks who were on alms-round witnessed the aftermath of this incident - children crying with injuries, parents arguing, and the whole neighborhood in turmoil. When they returned to the monastery, they related what they had seen to the Buddha. The Buddha asked them how the fight had started. The monks explained that it had begun with harsh words between two children during a game, which then escalated into an exchange of insults, which finally erupted into physical violence. The Buddha nodded sadly and said, 'This is the natural progression of harsh speech. It leads to retaliation, escalation, and eventually physical harm.' Then the Buddha spoke this verse: 'Speak not harshly to anyone. Those thus spoken to will retort. Painful indeed is vindictive speech. Blows in exchange may bruise you.' The Buddha explained: 'When someone speaks harshly, the natural human reaction is to speak back even more harshly. This harsh speech itself is painful - it hurts to hear insulting or aggressive words, and it hurts to speak them, as it agitates the mind. But beyond this immediate pain, harsh speech often leads to physical violence. Words wound the heart, and wounded hearts often strike back with fists. Those children began with only words, but their harsh speech led inevitably to blows and bloodshed.' The Buddha continued: 'This is why the wise person guards their speech carefully. Even when provoked, even when others speak harshly to them, they respond with gentle words or remain silent. They understand that harsh words, like blows, have a boomerang effect - they come back to harm the speaker. If you speak harshly, you will be spoken to harshly. If harsh speech continues, violence often follows. But if you refuse to engage in harsh speech, you break the cycle before it escalates to violence.' The Buddha advised: 'When someone speaks roughly to you, pause before responding. Remember that harsh words lead to more harsh words, and harsh words lead to blows. Take a breath. Calm your mind. Then either respond gently and respectfully, or remain silent. In this way, you protect yourself and others from the escalating pain of verbal and physical violence.' The monks took this teaching back to their communities, and many people learned to be more careful with their speech, understanding that harsh words were the seeds of greater conflicts.

verses.pali:
Sace neresi attānaṁ, kaṁso upahato yathā;
Esa pattosi nibbānaṁ, sārambho te na vijjati.
verses.translation: If, like a cracked gong, you silence yourself, you have already attained Nibbāna; in you no contention is found.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the simile of a cracked gong that makes no sound when struck. A normal gong resonates when hit, but a cracked one remains silent. Similarly, when a person is insulted or attacked but does not react with anger or retaliation, they demonstrate a state close to Nibbāna. 'Sārambho' means contention, quarrel, or hostility. When there is no reactive hostility in one's mind, one has achieved a state of peace similar to Nibbāna. This verse teaches the importance of non-retaliation and equanimity in the face of provocation.

story.title: The Story of the Ascetic Santati
story.content: Santati was a minister in King Pasenadi's court who lived a life of luxury and power. One day, he attended a teaching by the Buddha at the king's invitation. As he listened to the Dhamma, his mind became deeply moved and he attained the first stage of enlightenment (Stream-entry) right there. Immediately after the discourse, Santati approached the Buddha and requested ordination. The Buddha, seeing his readiness and sincerity, accepted him into the Sangha. Santati gave away all his wealth and possessions and became a monk. He practiced diligently and soon attained Arahantship, becoming completely free from all defilements. One day, not long after his attainment, Santati was on alms-round in the city. He happened to pass by his former mansion where he had lived in luxury. His former wife, who had not yet accepted his departure from household life, saw him walking past. She was still angry and resentful about his decision to become a monk, which she saw as abandoning her. Unable to contain her bitterness, she came out of the house and began to abuse Santati verbally in front of many people. She shouted insults at him, calling him ungrateful, irresponsible, and heartless. She accused him of caring nothing for her welfare after all the years they had spent together. She mocked his monk's robes and his choice to beg for food when he could have continued to live in wealth. The crowd gathered, expecting to see how the former minister would respond to this public humiliation. Some people felt uncomfortable hearing a woman abuse a monk in this way. Others waited to see if Santati would defend himself or respond to her accusations. But Venerable Santati stood there in complete silence, his face calm and peaceful, showing no sign of anger, hurt, or defensive reaction. He simply maintained his composure, like a cracked gong that makes no sound when struck. His mind remained equanimous, unmoved by the harsh words. When the woman finally exhausted her anger and fell silent, Santati simply moved on with his alms-round, continuing peacefully as if nothing had happened. The crowd was astonished. Many people were deeply impressed by his perfect self-control and inner peace. Some of the witnesses went to the Buddha and described what they had seen. They asked, 'How could Venerable Santati remain so completely unmoved by such harsh public abuse? Most people would have been deeply hurt or angry. But he showed not the slightest disturbance. How is this possible?' The Buddha smiled and said, 'Santati has attained Arahantship. He has completely eliminated anger, pride, and all reactive patterns from his mind. When harsh words are spoken to him, there is no anger to arise. When he is insulted, there is no wounded pride to defend. His mind is like a cracked gong that cannot resonate - when struck with harsh words, it makes no sound of retaliation or disturbance.' Then the Buddha spoke this verse: 'If, like a cracked gong, you silence yourself, you have already attained Nibbāna; in you no contention is found.' The Buddha explained further: 'A normal person, when criticized or insulted, immediately feels anger arise. The mind resonates with the harsh words, generating hostile thoughts and often harsh words in return. This reaction is automatic and natural for the unenlightened. But one who has attained Nibbāna has eliminated the conditions for such reactions. When harsh words come, they find nothing to disturb, like a sound wave hitting a cracked gong that cannot vibrate. This perfect non-reaction is a sign of having attained the highest peace. It is not suppression of anger - it is the complete absence of anger. It is not forced silence - it is natural peace.' The Buddha continued: 'All of you should take Venerable Santati as an example. Train yourselves not to react with hostility when provoked. When someone speaks harshly to you, pause before responding. Watch your mind. Notice the tendency to react with anger or defensive words. Instead of following that tendency, simply remain silent, calm, and peaceful. As you practice this more and more, your reactions will become less intense, until eventually, like an Arahant, you can remain perfectly peaceful no matter what others say or do. This is true spiritual accomplishment.'

verses.pali:
Yathā daṇḍena gopālo, gāvo pājeti gocaraṁ;
Evaṁ jarā ca maccu ca, āyuṁ pājenti pāṇinaṁ.
verses.translation: Just as a cowherd drives the cattle to pasture with a staff, so do old age and death drive the life of beings.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the simile of a cowherd driving cattle to illustrate how all beings are driven by old age (jarā) and death (maccu). Just as cattle have no choice but to move where the cowherd directs them with his staff, all living beings are helplessly driven by the forces of aging and death. This verse emphasizes the inevitability and universality of aging and death, serving as a reminder of urgency in spiritual practice. We should not delay in practicing the Dhamma, as old age and death are constantly pushing us forward.

story.title: The Story of a Group of Women
story.content: In Sāvatthī, there was a group of women who were close friends. They had known each other since childhood and had grown up together. As young girls, they had played together, laughed together, and shared their dreams of the future. As they grew into young women, they celebrated together, supporting each other through life's joys and sorrows. They all married around the same time and started families together. Their children played together just as they had. Life seemed happy and stable. Years passed, and the women continued to meet regularly, sharing meals and stories. But gradually, they began to notice changes. Gray hairs appeared. Their skin lost its youthful glow. They moved more slowly. Simple tasks that once were effortless now required more effort. One by one, their parents died. Then their husbands began to age visibly as well. Some became ill. One day, one of the women - who had been the most vibrant and cheerful of the group - fell seriously ill and died suddenly. The remaining friends were shocked and grieved deeply. They had lost others before, but this was one of their own circle, someone their own age. Not long after, another of the group passed away. Then another. The survivors began to realize with growing horror that they too were approaching the end. Old age and death, which had once seemed distant concerns, were now their constant reality. The remaining women, now elderly and few in number, went together to see the Buddha. They told him their story - how they had been young together, how life had seemed full of promise, how they had expected to grow old peacefully. But instead, they had watched their group diminish, one friend after another taken by death. Now they were old themselves and frightened. One of the women asked the Buddha, 'Venerable Sir, when we were young, we never thought about death. It seemed so far away. We were busy with our families, our homes, our daily activities. We thought we had time. But now death has claimed most of our friends, and we see that it is coming for us too. How did this happen? Why were we not more aware?' The Buddha looked at them with compassion and said, 'This is the way of all conditioned existence. From the moment we are born, old age and death drive us forward like a cowherd drives cattle with his staff. We have no choice in this. We cannot stop aging. We cannot avoid death. These forces push us relentlessly forward whether we wish it or not.' Then the Buddha spoke this verse: 'Just as a cowherd drives the cattle to pasture with a staff, so do old age and death drive the life of beings.' The Buddha explained: 'Think of cattle being driven to pasture. The cowherd walks behind them with his staff, and they must go where he directs. If they stop or try to turn back, he prods them forward with his staff. They have no choice but to move in the direction he drives them. In exactly the same way, all beings are driven by old age and death. From the moment of birth, we are being pushed toward old age. From the moment we begin to age, we are being pushed toward death. We cannot stop. We cannot turn back. We cannot resist these forces. Old age and death prod us constantly forward like that cowherd's staff.' The Buddha continued: 'You ask why you were not more aware when you were young. The truth is that old age and death were driving you even then, but you did not notice because you were looking in other directions. You were focused on youth, beauty, pleasure, family, and worldly affairs. These things distracted you from seeing the relentless approach of old age and death. But they were there all along, pushing you forward year by year, day by day, moment by moment.' The women asked, 'What should we have done differently? What should we do now?' The Buddha replied, 'When you are young and strong, that is the time to practice the Dhamma diligently. That is when you have the energy and capability to make spiritual progress. Do not wait until old age and death are obviously near. Start practicing immediately, because old age and death are already driving you forward whether you see them or not.' The Buddha added, 'But it is never too late to begin. Even now, in your old age, you can practice. The time left to you is uncertain, but whatever time you have, use it wisely. Practice mindfulness. Contemplate impermanence. Let go of attachment. Even if death comes tomorrow, you can spend today creating merit and purifying your mind. This is the most important use of whatever life remains.' The women took refuge in the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha, and devoted their remaining years to practice. Though they had little time left, they practiced with great urgency and mindfulness, understanding that old age and death were driving them forward and that every moment was precious. The Buddha used this story to teach all beings: Do not delay in spiritual practice. Do not think you have unlimited time. Old age and death are driving you forward right now, in this very moment. Practice now, while you still can.

verses.pali:
Atha pāpāni kammāni, karaṁ bālo na bujjhati;
Sehi kammehi dummedho, aggidaḍḍho'va tappati.
verses.translation: When the fool commits evil deeds, he does not realize their nature. The witless person is tormented by his own deeds, like one burnt by fire.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the fool's lack of understanding regarding the consequences of evil actions. The fool (bāla) commits evil without recognizing that these actions will bring future suffering. The word 'dummedho' (witless, lacking wisdom) emphasizes this ignorance. Later, when the karmic consequences ripen, the fool suffers intensely, like someone being burned by fire. The simile of fire illustrates both the intensity and self-inflicted nature of this suffering - just as someone who grasps fire burns themselves, the fool who commits evil creates their own future torment. The verse teaches that evil deeds, even when committed in ignorance, inevitably produce painful results.

story.title: The Story of the Crocodile Peta
story.content: In a forest near Sāvatthī, there lived a peta (hungry ghost) who had been reborn in that miserable state as a result of evil karma from a previous life. This particular peta had an unusual and horrifying appearance - his body resembled a crocodile, covered in tough, scaly skin. But unlike a normal crocodile that lives in water, this peta was consumed by flames. Fire constantly burned his body from within, causing him unbearable agony. He could find no relief, no water to cool his burning form, no rest from the torment. The peta wandered through the forest, groaning in pain, occasionally visible to people with refined spiritual faculties. One day, the Elder Moggallāna, who possessed great psychic powers and could see beings in various realms, was walking through the forest on his alms-round. He perceived this crocodile-peta suffering in flames and felt great compassion. Having the ability to communicate with beings in other realms, he stopped and asked the peta, 'Friend, what evil deed did you commit in your past life that has resulted in this terrible suffering? Why do you appear as a crocodile, and why are you being burned by fire?' The peta, grateful for this opportunity to tell his story, replied with great anguish: 'Venerable Sir, in my previous life, I was a human being. I lived near a river where many fish and crocodiles could be found. I was a fisherman by trade, but I was particularly cruel in my methods. I did not simply catch fish to sell or eat. I took pleasure in causing suffering. When I caught fish, I would sometimes torture them for my amusement before killing them. I would pull out their scales one by one while they were still alive, watching them writhe in pain. Sometimes I would leave them to die slowly in the sun, gasping for water. But my worst deed involved crocodiles. One day, I managed to trap a young crocodile in my net. Instead of killing it quickly or releasing it, I decided to burn it alive. I poured oil over the creature and set it on fire, watching with cruel satisfaction as it thrashed and struggled in the flames until it died. I felt no remorse for this action. I thought it was just an animal and that what I did to it didn't matter. I believed I would face no consequences. I was a fool, lacking wisdom. I did not understand the law of karma - that every action, good or bad, produces corresponding results. I did not realize that I was creating the causes for my own future suffering. I committed these evil deeds without understanding their nature or their consequences.' The peta continued, now weeping in anguish: 'After I died, I was immediately reborn in this wretched state. Because I had burned that crocodile alive, I now have the form of a crocodile that is constantly burned by flames. Because I tortured fish and took pleasure in their suffering, I now experience unbearable agony myself. This torture has continued for a very long time, and I do not know when it will end. Every moment is excruciating. I am burned continuously by fire from within, and there is no escape, no relief, no moment of peace. I am tormented by my own deeds, suffering the exact consequences of the suffering I inflicted on others. Now, too late, I understand the law of karma. Now, too late, I wish I had been wise enough to avoid evil actions. But when I was alive, I was a fool. I did not realize what I was doing to myself.' Elder Moggallāna, deeply moved by this account, returned to the monastery and related the peta's story to the other monks. The monks were shocked and asked the Buddha about it. The Buddha confirmed that what Elder Moggallāna had witnessed was true. The Buddha then spoke this verse: 'When the fool commits evil deeds, he does not realize their nature. The witless person is tormented by his own deeds, like one burnt by fire.' The Buddha explained further: 'This peta was indeed a fool when he was alive. He committed terrible acts of cruelty, believing there would be no consequences. He lacked the wisdom to understand that harming other beings creates the causes for one's own suffering. He did not realize the nature of his evil actions - that they were planting seeds of future torment. Now he suffers intensely, burned by fire just as he burned that crocodile, tormented just as he tormented those fish. His suffering is self-created, the direct result of his own evil karma. This is what happens to those who commit evil in ignorance, without understanding the law of cause and effect.' The Buddha used this story to teach an important lesson about the relationship between ignorance, evil actions, and suffering. He emphasized that ignorance of karmic law does not protect one from its consequences. Just as someone who touches fire gets burned whether they understand the nature of fire or not, someone who commits evil will suffer the consequences whether they understand karma or not. The Buddha concluded: 'This is why wisdom is so essential. The wise person understands the nature of actions and their consequences. Understanding this, they carefully avoid all evil and cultivate only good. The fool, lacking this understanding, commits evil freely, not realizing they are creating their own future hell. Do not be like this fool. Develop wisdom. Understand the law of karma. Avoid all evil, knowing that every harmful action you commit is like grasping fire - it will surely burn you.'

verses.pali:
Yo daṇḍena adaṇḍesu, appaduṭṭhesu dussati;
Dasannamaññataraṁ ṭhānaṁ, khippam eva nigacchati.
verses.translation: Whoever harms with violence the harmless who should not be hurt, quickly comes to one of ten states of woe.
verses.commentary: This verse warns of severe consequences for harming innocent beings. The word 'adaṇḍesu' means those who carry no weapon, i.e., the harmless or innocent. 'Appaduṭṭhesu' means those who are not hostile. When someone harms such innocent beings, they quickly (khippam eva) experience one of ten states of suffering. These ten states are enumerated in the following verses.

story.title: The Story of Elder Moggallāna
story.content: Elder Moggallāna, one of the Buddha's two chief disciples, possessed extraordinary psychic powers. He could travel to various realms, see beings in different states of existence, and understand past lives. One day, heretical teachers who were jealous of the Buddha's popularity hired assassins to kill Moggallāna. The assassins attacked him with clubs and broke his bones. Though he could have used his psychic powers to escape or defend himself, Moggallāna understood this was the result of his own past karma ripening and accepted it. He died from the attack and attained Parinibbāna. The Buddha explained that in a past life, Moggallāna had killed his own parents at the instigation of his wife. This grave evil deed had followed him through many lifetimes, and even though he had attained Arahantship in this life, the physical karma still ripened. The Buddha spoke these verses to warn others about the serious consequences of harming innocent beings.

verses.pali:
Vedanaṁ pharusaṁ jāniṁ, sarīrassa ca bhedanaṁ;
Garukaṁ vāpi ābādhaṁ, cittakkhepañca pāpuṇe.
verses.translation: One may suffer acute pain, disaster, bodily injury, serious illness, or derangement of mind.
verses.commentary: This verse lists five of the ten states of suffering that can result from harming the innocent: acute pain (vedanaṁ pharusaṁ), disaster or loss (jāniṁ), physical injury (sarīrassa bhedanaṁ), serious illness (garukaṁ ābādhaṁ), or mental derangement (cittakkhepañca). These are not merely theoretical possibilities but actual consequences that manifest in the lives of those who harm the harmless.

story.title: Examples of the Ten States
story.content: The Buddha gave various examples of people who experienced these states of suffering. Some suffered excruciating physical pain as karmic retribution. Others lost their wealth and possessions suddenly. Some received severe physical injuries. Many developed serious diseases. And some lost their mental faculties, becoming insane or deranged. All these were results of having harmed innocent beings in this or previous lives.

verses.pali:
Rājato vā upassaggaṁ, abbhakkhānañca dāruṇaṁ;
Parikkhayañca ñātīnaṁ, bhogānañca pabhaṅguraṁ.
verses.translation: Or trouble from the government, or grave accusations, or loss of relatives, or destruction of wealth.
verses.commentary: This verse lists four more of the ten states: persecution by the government or ruler (rājato upassaggaṁ), false and grave accusations (abbhakkhānañca dāruṇaṁ), death or loss of relatives (parikkhayañca ñātīnaṁ), or destruction of one's wealth (bhogānañca pabhaṅguraṁ). These worldly calamities are also karmic consequences of harming the innocent. The Buddha wanted people to understand that harming others creates conditions for one's own suffering in multiple ways.

story.title: Continuation of Examples
story.content: The Buddha cited cases where people who had harmed innocent beings later faced persecution from kings, were falsely accused of crimes, lost their family members to death or separation, or saw their wealth destroyed by fire, flood, theft, or confiscation. These were all manifestations of the karma created by harming those who should not be harmed.

verses.pali:
Atha vāssa agārāni, aggi ḍahati pāvako;
Kāyassa bhedā duppañño, nirayaṁ so upapajjati.
verses.translation: Or his houses are destroyed by fire. Upon the dissolution of the body, the fool is reborn in hell.
verses.commentary: This verse completes the ten states of suffering with the tenth: destruction of one's home by fire (agārāni aggi ḍahati). But more seriously, it states that after death, such a fool who has harmed the innocent is reborn in hell (nirayaṁ upapajjati). This is the ultimate consequence - not just suffering in this life, but rebirth in states of extreme torment. The 'fool' (duppañño) here refers to one who lacks the wisdom to avoid harming others.

story.title: The Final Consequence
story.content: The Buddha explained that while the first nine states of suffering occur in this present life as immediate karmic results, the tenth and most severe consequence comes after death. Those who have harmed innocent beings, especially holy persons or those who have done no wrong, create such heavy negative karma that they are reborn in hell realms where they experience suffering far more intense and prolonged than any earthly misfortune. This teaching served as a strong deterrent against violence toward the innocent.

verses.pali:
Na naggacariyā na jaṭā na paṅkā, nānāsakā thaṇḍilasāyikā vā;
Rajo va jallaṁ ukkuṭikappadhānaṁ, sodhenti maccaṁ avitiṇṇakaṅkhaṁ.
verses.translation: Not nakedness, nor matted hair, nor filth, nor fasting, nor sleeping on the ground, nor smearing oneself with ashes, nor austere squatting can purify a mortal who has not overcome doubt.
verses.commentary: This verse criticizes external religious austerities when practiced without internal purification. The Buddha lists various ascetic practices common in India: going naked, wearing matted hair, covering oneself with dirt, fasting, sleeping on hard ground, smearing ashes on the body, and maintaining uncomfortable postures. While some ascetics believed these practices led to purification, the Buddha teaches that they cannot cleanse a person who has not overcome fundamental doubts about the Dhamma and who has not purified their mind of defilements. True purification comes from wisdom and virtue, not from external mortifications.

story.title: The Story of Bahubhaṇḍika (Many Possessions)
story.content: There was a monk named Bahubhaṇḍika who kept many possessions despite having ordained. He had numerous robes, bowls, and other requisites. Other monks criticized him for this, comparing him unfavorably with austere ascetics who owned nothing and practiced severe austerities. When the Buddha was asked about this, he explained that external austerities without internal purity are worthless, while a monk like Bahubhaṇḍika, despite having possessions, could be pure in mind and practice. The Buddha spoke these verses to show that what matters is the state of one's mind and the purity of one's conduct, not external appearance or austerities.

verses.pali:
Alaṅkato cepi samaṁ careyya, santo danto niyato brahmacārī;
Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṁ, so brāhmaṇo so samaṇo sa bhikkhu.
verses.translation: Even though adorned, if one lives peacefully, is calmed, controlled, certain, living the holy life, and has laid aside violence towards all beings, he is a brahmin, an ascetic, a bhikkhu.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the opposite view - that external appearance doesn't determine spiritual attainment. Even someone who is well-dressed and adorned (alaṅkato) can be a true spiritual person if they possess the essential qualities: inner peace (santo), self-control (danto), certainty in the Dhamma (niyato), practice of the holy life (brahmacārī), and non-violence toward all beings (sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṁ). Such a person deserves to be called a true brahmin, ascetic, or monk, regardless of external appearance. True renunciation is internal, not merely external.

story.title: The Story of Santati the Minister
story.content: Santati was a wealthy minister who, while attending a Dhamma talk, attained Stream-entry and immediately requested ordination. He became a monk and soon attained Arahantship. Even though he had lived in luxury before ordination and didn't practice extreme austerities, his mind was completely pure. The Buddha explained that Santati was a true monk not because of any external practices but because he had completely purified his mind, was established in virtue, lived the holy life perfectly, and harmed no living being. His internal attainment made him a genuine spiritual practitioner, regardless of how recently he had been living in worldly splendor.

verses.pali:
Hirīnisedho puriso, koci lokasmiṁ vijjati;
Yo niddaṁ apabodhati, asso bhadro kasāmiva.
verses.translation: Rare in this world is the person restrained by modesty, who avoids reproach as a trained horse avoids the whip.
verses.commentary: This verse praises the quality of hiri (moral shame or modesty) - the sense of conscience that restrains one from evil. The Buddha says it is rare (koci) to find someone who is restrained by this inner moral sense and who naturally avoids blame-worthy actions, just as a well-trained horse needs no whip because it naturally does what is right. Most people need external constraints, but the truly virtuous are guided by their own sense of shame at doing wrong.

story.title: The Story of Pilotikatissa
story.content: Venerable Pilotikatissa was a monk known for his extreme caution and modesty. He was so concerned about doing anything that might be criticized or might bring reproach to the Sangha that he was overly careful in all his actions. Some monks thought he was being excessive in his caution. When the Buddha was consulted, he praised Pilotikatissa's attitude.
